comment.author: 25453448@N02
comment._content: This view has scarcely changed since the photo was taken - compare with Google Street

comment.author: 83025347@N00
comment._content: Wow, can't believe it still looks the same. That's fantastic. Here's another modern view, somewhat marred by construction barriers: www.flickr.com/photos/davellandudno/70613085/

comment.author: 25453448@N02
comment._content: The building on the corner facing us is 1 Bridge Street. It is a Grade II* Listed Building. It is not particularly old, being late19th Century, and completed in 1888, i.e. not long before the photo was taken (there are much older things nearby: Medieval and Roman). However, its style is inspired by Tudor (16th Century) house building. I've always imagined the inspiration is Little Moreton Hall, a well-known 16th Century half-timbered mansion not far from Chester, in the same county (Cheshire).

comment.author: 83025347@N00
comment._content: Here in the US, a building from 1888 would be considered old and obsolete. A developer from out of town would convince the city to give him money so he could demolish it, promising to build something ugly that would "create jobs." Then he would run out of money and the site would be turned into a car park.
